quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The core idea is ask for what you want. Turns out when you actually ask for what you want out loud, you're much more likely to get it.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A simple but high-leverage principle that frames the episode’s core skill as a practical behavior change.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If you're more in the people pleasing camp, maybe you're used to not asking at all. You're hoping that people are reading your mind. And if you're sort of more in the control freak camp, maybe you're used to ordering people around and saying, "Go do this now."
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A useful diagnostic framework for identifying two common failure modes in communication and requests.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Complaints are great inspiration. Every complaint implies a dream.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A memorable reframe that turns frustration into a method for discovering what you actually want.

quotes.topic_title: Why asking for what you want matters
quotes.text: If I had to answer in one word, it would be integrity.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Frames “asking for what you want” not as a communication tactic but as an integrity practice with high personal stakes.

quotes.topic_title: Why asking for what you want matters
quotes.text: But if we're asking for it regularly, if we're listening to the response, we're expecting the nose we get from the world, then we can get the sense of, "Yeah, I'm honoring what's important to me. I'm honoring the world's response and I'm moving forward towards what I want."
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Offers a repeatable method: ask regularly, listen, and treat “no” as expected feedback while staying aligned to what matters.

quotes.topic_title: Why asking for what you want matters
quotes.text: And if we don't do that, "Well, then we're fooling ourselves that we're actually moving towards of what we want."
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that not asking can create a false sense of progress toward your goals.

quotes.topic_title: Why asking for what you want matters
quotes.text: There tends to be all these unexpected secondary and tertiary effects that come out of that of stress and frustration, and unhappiness because of course, asking for what we want, pursuing what's important to us in life is just one of the most important things of fulfillment, of what's important in achieving our purpose.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Connects the practice of asking directly to downstream emotional outcomes and purpose/fulfillment, raising the cost of avoidance.

quotes.topic_title: Signs you’re struggling: stuckness and conflict
quotes.text: But if we're in the same stuck place week after week after week in our coaching sessions, probably you're trying the same thing and not getting any different results. It's that definition of insanity thing.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic for when “not asking effectively” is showing up as repeated stagnation.

quotes.topic_title: Signs you’re struggling: stuckness and conflict
quotes.text: So why are we not learning from that? Why are we not moving forward getting new data, trying something new, actually treating it as a sort of iterative development discovery process?
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Reframes interpersonal/work progress as an iterative loop—run experiments, gather data, adjust—rather than repeating the same approach.

quotes.topic_title: Signs you’re struggling: stuckness and conflict
quotes.text: I think another really common mode is coming with a lot of entitlement of, "You know what? You better do what I say. I'm your boss. You're my report. You better obey or agree," or whatever it is.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Highlights entitlement as a common failure mode of “asking,” explaining why it reliably creates conflict instead of influence.

quotes.topic_title: Signs you’re struggling: stuckness and conflict
quotes.text: it's fundamentally disrespectful to go into a meeting already deciding that you're right and the other person is wrong because you can't know that for sure.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A memorable standard for entering conversations with openness, especially relevant for high-conviction roles like PM.

quotes.topic_title: Signs you’re struggling: stuckness and conflict
quotes.text: And so I think often when the stakes feel high, we're kind of focused more on the fear of what we don't want to happen than on actually achieving what we do want.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A useful mental model for recognizing when fear is driving behavior and derailing effective asking toward clear goals.

quotes.topic_title: How to know what you want
quotes.text: So one of my favorite techniques here is this concept they call dream behind the complaint.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Introduces a practical framework for uncovering what you want by working backward from what you complain about.

quotes.topic_title: How to know what you want
quotes.text: So the magic of that complaining is that every complaint implies a dream. It implies a better world where that complaint is resolved.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Reframes complaints as valuable signals that point to an underlying desired future state.

quotes.topic_title: How to know what you want
quotes.text: And then to really check, "Okay. Let's imagine you get that. That's the world of the future that you get. How does that feel? Is that big enough or is it kind of meh?"
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Gives a concrete self-test to pressure-check whether the implied “dream” is actually motivating and meaningful.

quotes.topic_title: How to know what you want
quotes.text: And so if your dream is so embarrassing to say out loud, you can't even really own it, maybe that's not the right dream.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Provides a credibility filter to distinguish authentic desires from unrealistic or ego-driven fantasies.

quotes.topic_title: How to know what you want
quotes.text: Because it's an iterative process. We're learning from the response and what it tells us because the response is usually no.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Normalizes rejection and frames asking as an iterative learning loop rather than a one-shot request.

quotes.topic_title: Fear of asking and the “hell yes” bar
quotes.text: So I have a more expansive definition of no than most people, I think, because for me it's not a yes unless it's a hell yes.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Defines a crisp decision bar (“hell yes”) to prevent false alignment and ambiguous commitments.

quotes.topic_title: Fear of asking and the “hell yes” bar
quotes.text: And so I think part of what I encourage people to do is, one, to really hear anything short of a hell yes as a no. So it's not a bad thing. Mostly the world tells us it's actually really great data.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Reframes “no” (and lukewarm yeses) as useful information rather than rejection, enabling iteration toward alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Fear of asking and the “hell yes” bar
quotes.text: Hey, I'm hearing maybe you're lukewarm on May 1st as a date. What would be a hell yes day for you where you could say, absolutely, we can deliver on that?
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Gives a practical script for converting vague agreement into a concrete, committed plan.

quotes.topic_title: Fear of asking and the “hell yes” bar
quotes.text: Some people call this a whole body yes because sometimes your head is saying yes, but your heart is saying no or your gut is saying no.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Introduces a somatic check (“whole body yes”) to detect misalignment even when words sound agreeable.

quotes.topic_title: Fear of asking and the “hell yes” bar
quotes.text: I know I'm not going to get it. I know I'm not guaranteed to get it. I'm not going to be attached to that. I know people aren't obligated to tell me yes, but I'm going to go forward anyway because I want it and that's enough.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Models a resilient mindset for asking—detaching from outcomes while still pursuing what matters.

quotes.topic_title: The three-step framework overview
quotes.text: The first step is articulating what you want.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Sets the first step of the practical framework and anchors the skill as the starting point for getting unstuck.

quotes.topic_title: The three-step framework overview
quotes.text: But for those folks, often what I'm encouraging that do is to really tune into the parts of them that maybe aren't so fine like, "Gosh, I'd prefer it a little bit if things were this way or yeah, I'm a little bit bothered by this, or I'm a little bit nervous about this."
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Actionable advice to use subtle negative emotions as signals for what you actually want, instead of defaulting to “I’m fine.”

quotes.topic_title: The three-step framework overview
quotes.text: And so kind of tuning more into those subtle emotions that are pointing them towards, "Sure, I'm okay with the status quo, but I want something more."
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A practical mental model: treat subtle emotions as directional indicators toward a clearer desire beyond the status quo.

quotes.topic_title: The three-step framework overview
quotes.text: And so helping them articulate that in a clearer way where they can want something without being attached to having to get it.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Counterintuitive but useful stance: separate wanting from attachment to outcome to make asking easier and more resilient.

quotes.topic_title: The three-step framework overview
quotes.text: So for those folks, it really tends to be more about saying it out loud. Once you say it out loud, it is clearer. That's not really what it's about.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A simple methodology: vocalizing an unrealistic goal helps reveal the deeper underlying need it’s trying to satisfy.

quotes.topic_title: Step 1: articulating wants with integrity checks
quotes.text: Because the thing about accepting other people's no is that, "Sure, they can always say no. Everybody gets to say no whenever they want, but there are consequences."
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Reframes “being nice” as still requiring clear consequences, which helps leaders articulate expectations without guilt.

quotes.topic_title: Step 1: articulating wants with integrity checks
quotes.text: Part of really respecting them is respecting that they can make the choices they want and they're grownups enough that they can deal with the consequences of those choices."
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Offers a mental model for delivering hard feedback: consequences are a form of respect and adult-to-adult leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Step 1: articulating wants with integrity checks
quotes.text: But they're not willing to go that extra step and say, "Yeah, but this is the call and I need you to actually follow through with that. I understand that might be disappointing or frustrating or what have you, but part of the expectation for this role is that you can roll with disagree and commit sometimes when that's necessary."
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Concrete example of articulating a want (disagree-and-commit) while acknowledging emotions and setting role expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Step 1: articulating wants with integrity checks
quotes.text: It always comes back to integrity. And a great way to do an integrity check is to just look have I fully expressed myself?
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Introduces an “integrity check” methodology for identifying unspoken wants before they become resentment or avoidance.

quotes.topic_title: Step 1: articulating wants with integrity checks
quotes.text: "Gosh, is there something that I keep thinking about and I'm just like three or four days, I'm just like, man, I really want to say this to this person." At this point, you're probably out of integrity because there's something deep in you that really needs to say this, right?
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Actionable diagnostic: recurring thoughts over days are a signal you’re withholding something important and should speak up.

quotes.topic_title: Step 2: asking intentionally vs default ruts
quotes.text: So for asking what you want, I think the really important tweak here is asking intentionally because I think a lot of us are stuck on a certain track that's comfortable for us when we ask.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Introduces the core mental shift: move from habitual “default” asking patterns to deliberate, intentional asks.

quotes.topic_title: Step 2: asking intentionally vs default ruts
quotes.text: So part of asking for what you want effectively is really just recognizing the rut that you get stuck in and working through all those narratives that make us resist asking it a different way.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Offers a practical method: identify your default rut and interrogate the stories that keep you from changing it.

quotes.topic_title: Step 2: asking intentionally vs default ruts
quotes.text: Even implicit in that question, to me that's that question of, "Oh, how do I do it without being any risk of ever pissing anyone off?" That's a piece of the resistance right there.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reframe: the desire to eliminate interpersonal risk is itself what prevents progress.

quotes.topic_title: Step 2: asking intentionally vs default ruts
quotes.text: But often we get stuck so we don't get to go through those levels of iteration because we want to make sure we're going to get the outcome.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Highlights an execution trap: demanding certainty blocks the iteration needed to learn how to ask effectively.

quotes.topic_title: Step 2: asking intentionally vs default ruts
quotes.text: I think one of the most important balances in terms of the asking step is both asking clearly, but asking with great humility.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Gives a portable principle for ICs and leaders alike: combine clarity with humility to make strong asks without overreaching.

quotes.topic_title: Asking with humility and using influence without data
quotes.text: I think one of the most important balances in terms of the asking step is both asking clearly, but asking with great humility.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A simple, actionable principle for influencing decisions: be direct about what you want while staying humble about your authority and certainty.

quotes.topic_title: Asking with humility and using influence without data
quotes.text: But actually, if you go the other direction and you're humble and you say, "I know I can't make you do anything, it's not my call to make. But man, this is really what I want. I'm just going to put it out there and ask."
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A concrete script practitioners can use to ask for change without positional power or perfect evidence.

quotes.topic_title: Asking with humility and using influence without data
quotes.text: That I think it feels really vulnerable and uncomfortable to not lean on data as a sort of way of saying, "No, no, I'm right, so you should believe what I believe." But just say, "Actually, I don't know that I'm right. This is just what I think and I hope that's enough on its own."
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A counterintuitive take that influence can come from candid judgment and vulnerability—not just data-backed certainty.

quotes.topic_title: Asking with humility and using influence without data
quotes.text: So we don't have the data of all those gut opinions of these subject matter experts in the room, even though that gut information to me is just as important as anything we could get from the SQL database or whatever.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Highlights a blind spot in data-driven cultures: failing to capture expert intuition as a valuable input alongside quantitative metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Asking with humility and using influence without data
quotes.text: To me, complaints are great inspiration.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Reframes complaining as a diagnostic signal that can be converted into a clear ask and desired outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Complaints as signals and embracing “parts”
quotes.text: To me, complaints are great inspiration.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Reframes complaining as a useful signal you can mine for what you actually want to ask for.

quotes.topic_title: Complaints as signals and embracing “parts”
quotes.text: But to say, "And I want something. I would like to see an outcome."
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Turns feedback into an actionable ask by explicitly naming the desired outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Complaints as signals and embracing “parts”
quotes.text: What am I frustrated about? Let me envision that better future. Let me think about what's an effective way to actually move towards that. What's an effective way to communicate that desire that's actually likely to get me towards a yes?
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Provides a practical self-coaching sequence for converting frustration into an effective request.

quotes.topic_title: Complaints as signals and embracing “parts”
quotes.text: So really to sort of ask effectively, we generally need to embrace all these parts and really bring in all the information they're bringing in because if we ignore the part that's really scared to ask, well, then we're going to stay stuck.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Introduces a “parts” methodology for working with internal resistance instead of suppressing it.

quotes.topic_title: Complaints as signals and embracing “parts”
quotes.text: And by embracing that, instead of ignoring that and being ashamed of that, that is often how we soften those fears and say, "I know that's scary, but we also know that's not really true. You're not an imposter, right? You're an experienced professional."
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Shows a concrete script for validating fear/shame and then gently updating it with reality to enable action.

quotes.topic_title: Feedback frameworks and staying factual
quotes.text: I took one of Stanford's T-Group Weekends, summer of 2020, I think a month after George Floyd was murdered and was facilitated by a black woman. And it was one of the most profound transformative weekends of my life.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A concrete example of an intense, structured interpersonal-learning experience that shaped his approach to working with people.

quotes.topic_title: Feedback frameworks and staying factual
quotes.text: And it's basically when you want to give someone feedback, the template is when you do a behavior, I feel a feeling, and she's big on like say actual feeling word not like, "I feel like, or I feel that," blah, blah, blah. And step three is, "I'm telling you this because..." and then what you want them to change.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical, repeatable feedback template that increases clarity and receptivity by separating behavior, emotion, and request.

quotes.topic_title: Feedback frameworks and staying factual
quotes.text: So there's kind of rough consensus in the sort of personal development world of how to ask. And really what they have in common is around staying really factual because I think that what can we know factually well? We can know our thoughts, we can know our feelings because no one else can know that better than us. Maybe we can trust our eyes. What would a video camera have recorded? And that's about it.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A mental model for grounding feedback/asks in what’s verifiable: internal experience plus observable, camera-recordable facts.

quotes.topic_title: Feedback frameworks and staying factual
quotes.text: So I think often we get really distracted by all these stories we have about the data, but when we bring it back to that fundamental core of this is what I think, this is what I feel, this is what I've observed in the world, it tends to make the ask a lot clearer versus these stories like you mentioned of, "I feel like you're an asshole." It's like, "Well, that's a story. That's not a fact."
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A counter to common feedback habits: labeling and interpretation obscure the actionable request, while facts + feelings clarify it.

quotes.topic_title: Step 3: accepting the response and iterating
quotes.text: But step three is accept the response. And it might seem so simple, but it actually is kind of subtle.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Frames “accepting the response” as a deceptively hard skill, setting up why practitioners need to treat it as a distinct step.

quotes.topic_title: Step 3: accepting the response and iterating
quotes.text: Because I think sometimes what people who are really afraid to ask will do is they say, oh, well, that was a no. So it's no forever and I should never ask again. My dream is dead and nothing is ever going to happen for me again." And that's because they get so scared. But actually no, that's over accepting. The no is just from this person right now in the way that you asked, which doesn't necessarily mean anything about the next time you ask to a different person in a different way, in a different time.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Introduces the “over-accepting” failure mode and a practical reframe: a “no” is contextual, not permanent.

quotes.topic_title: Step 3: accepting the response and iterating
quotes.text: When we're talking about asking for what we want, we're talking about influence. So you need to have good relationships. You can't be influential with a bad relationship.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Connects effective asking to influence and relationship quality, making it actionable to prioritize respect and trust over force.

quotes.topic_title: Step 3: accepting the response and iterating
quotes.text: Because I think the counterintuitive thing is that often when we really respect people's no's, it can actually be more influential, more motivating.
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: A contrarian leadership insight: honoring “no” can increase motivation and influence more than pushing for compliance.

quotes.topic_title: Step 3: accepting the response and iterating
quotes.text: Acceptance of the response is primarily an emotional regulation issue because once we get our emotions intact, it's just, is it yes or is it no? And if it's no, which it probably is, most of the time the world tells us no, then the question is, "All right, what can I learn from this? What am I going to try next?"
quotes.speaker: Kenneth Berger
quotes.context: Offers a practical methodology: regulate emotions so “no” becomes clear data that drives iteration and next experiments.
